abstract.p: Steve Teeter letter, commenting on August 26 letters, says Survivor television program was only game, cleverly dressed up to look like reality

block.p: Re '' 'Survivor,' and Our Lives Today'' (letters, Aug. 26):

Does anyone fret about the moral implications of laying a trap for a chess opponent? Do we worry about the implications for society's value system when one poker player bluffs another into folding? Of course not. A ruthless poker player can be the soul of virtue and decency when he gets up from the table.
Re '' 'Survivor,' and Our Lives Today'' (letters, Aug. 26):

Does anyone fret about the moral implications of laying a trap for a chess opponent? Do we worry about the implications for society's value system when one poker player bluffs another into folding? Of course not. A ruthless poker player can be the soul of virtue and decency when he gets up from the table.
In those cases, we keep in mind what many seem to have forgotten about ''Survivor''; it was only a game, cleverly dressed up to look like ''reality.'' Yet it seems many viewers mistook it for that.
Richard Hatch understood that a certain amount of Machiavellian scheming was needed to win. Judging his real-world morals and character by his game play is unfair and naive.
